item.title: EU leaders to agree on top jobs despite Meloni discontent
item.description: The Italian leader has made it clear she resents having been left out of a deal to divide up the EU's top jobs.

item.title: China's Communist Party Expels 2 Former Ministers Over Corruption: Report
item.description: China's Communist Party on Thursday expelled former defence minister Li Shangfu and his predecessor Wei Fenghe for "serious violations of discipline", a euphemism for corruption, state news agency Xinhua reported.

item.title: Labour to seek ‘stable position’ with Europe rather than reopen Brexit debate
item.description:
Shadow business secretary says trying to rejoin single market or customs union would cause ‘more difficulties’

Labour would rather have stability in the UK’s relationship with the Europe than try to seek accelerated economic growth by rejoining the EU’s single market or customs union, the party’s shadow business secretary has said.

Addressing the British Chambers of Commerce (BCC) conference on Thursday, Jonathan Reynolds acknowledged that Brexit had been “very difficult for businesses” because it erected trade barriers, but said reopening the debate would be worse.

Continue reading...

item.title: Met officer charged over alleged theft from man who died after collapsing
item.description:
Scotland Yard says officer has been charged with misconduct in public office over alleged theft of money

A Metropolitan police officer has been charged with misconduct in public office over the alleged theft of money from a man who died after collapsing, the force has said.

More details soon …

Continue reading...

item.title: ‘At least’ seven Met officers under investigation over general election bets
item.description:
Met and Gambling Commission to focus on whether alleged use of confidential information constitutes cheating

  • UK election live – latest updates

The number of Metropolitan police officers under investigation over bets on the timing of the general election has risen to at least seven, the force has said.

Britain’s biggest police force said it would continue to investigate a “small number” of wagers as part of a joint investigation led by the Gambling Commission.

Continue reading...

item.title: Starmer says people would not be sent back to Afghanistan under returns policy
item.description:
Labour leader says halting of asylum processing due to government’s Rwanda policy ‘absurd and reckless’

  • UK election live – latest updates

Keir Starmer has admitted for the first time that he would not return people to Afghanistan, after a bitter exchange in Wednesday night’s debate where Rishi Sunak mocked him for planning to “sit down with the ayatollahs” to negotiate return agreements.

Starmer has repeatedly said he plans to negotiate returns agreements with safe countries in order to clear the asylum backlog, which has worsened due to the government’s recent legislation which does not allow asylum seekers to be processed while it waits to start deportations to Rwanda.

Continue reading...
